content: The "STEM Education Act of 2014" defines STEM education as education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, including computer science. It applies to various government agencies for carrying out STEM education activities. The STEM Education Act of 2014 defines STEM education as including science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and computer science. The National Science Foundation awards grants for research and development in out-of-school STEM learning, informal STEM education, and improving STEM learning outcomes. Grants support activities that enhance understanding of learning and engagement in informal environments to broaden participation in STEM. The National Science Foundation awards grants for research and development in out-of-school STEM learning, informal STEM education, and improving STEM learning outcomes. Grants support activities to broaden participation in STEM and design innovative STEM learning models for K-12 students, teachers, and the general public. The Noyce Scholarship Program is being amended. Amendments are made to the National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002, including changes to qualifications for Teaching Fellowships for teachers with master's or bachelor's degrees in their field. Teaching Fellowships for teachers with bachelor's degrees in their field and working toward a master's degree offer academic courses, leadership training, and programs for becoming highly effective mathematics and science teachers. The National Science Foundation is amending its program to support Master Teaching Fellows enrolled in a master's degree program. Fellows may receive up to 1 year of fellowship support while enrolled, with prorated amounts for part-time programs. Additionally, the definition of science in the NSF Authorization Act is expanded to include computer science. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 14, 2014, as attested by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
